dmca.title: Notice of Trademark Infringement - centraljewellery.com
dmca.body:
Dear Mr. Decker:

 

We are in receipt of your Trademark Complaint letter dated October 9,
2006. The disputed material in the above-referenced letter is the domain
name, not the content of the website. As an ISP, we are compelled by
Federal Law to disable access of website if it infringes copyright or
trademark rights of third parties. This is not the case since the
website www.centraljewellery.com neither uses the Trademark "jewelry
central" on his website nor has "jewelry central" content display there.
As the disputed material is the domain name and it is not under our
control, because it was not registered with us. This issue should be
resolved either by the registrar of the domain name centraljewellery.com
or ICANN.

 

Legal Response Team

-----Original Message-----
From: Jewelry Central [mailto:wdecker@jewelrycentral.com] 
Posted At: Monday, October 09, 2006 3:38 PM
Posted To: DMCA Houston
Conversation: Notice of Trademark Infringement - centraljewellery.com
Subject: Notice of Trademark Infringement - centraljewellery.com


William Decker
Legal Department
Jewelry Central
73 West 47th Street
New York, NY 10036 

October 9, 2006

Legal Department
Everyones Internet
1333 Stemmons Freeway Suite 110
Dallas, TX 75207

Re:   Notice of Trademark Infringement - centraljewellery.com

Terence Taylor - Central Jewellery
115 Clerkenwell Road
London, United Kingdom EC1R 5BY
info@centraljewellery.com

Dear Sir or Madam:

Jewelry Central is the owner of United States Trademark Registration
Numbers 2475526, 2894821 and 3067964 for the mark "JEWELRY CENTRAL".
Jewelry Central uses this mark in conjunction with "jewelrycentral.com",
which is an operating commercial web site. We have spent many years and
enormous financial resources in establishing our company's goodwill and
reputation.

It has come to our attention that your client has registered and is
using the above domain in violation of the Anticybersquatting Consumer
Protection Act of 1999, which is embodied in the Lanham Act.
Furthermore, your client is intentionally trading on the goodwill of
Jewelry Central by registering a domain that contains our mark and
internationally famous name. 

Everyones Internet is currently providing web hosting for the infringing
web site with the following name servers and ip address: NS2.EQHOST.NET,
NS1.EQHOST.NET, 207.44.186.39

It is clear that your client's registration and use in bad faith of the
infringing domain causes irreparable harm to Jewelry Central's
reputation, and is intended to confuse and misdirect consumers. This
activity is actionable under federal law and causes your client and
Everyones Internet to be liable to Jewelry Central in every state in
which sales have been made, and for all advertising revenue earned from
the use of the infringing domain. Your client's activities are unlawful
and constitute unfair competition, intentional trademark infringement,
trademark dilution, false designation of origin of goods and services,
cybersquatting, and the tarnishing of our mark. 

Demand is hereby made that Everyones Internet immediately deactivate the
infringing web site and prevent any further infringement of our mark
from occurring on your networks. In this regard we are willing to
negotiate a settlement to redress the infringement that has occurred to
date. You have our assurances that we will exhaust all available
remedies to vigorously protect our mark.

Demand is further made that Everyones Internet: (1) provide us with an
accounting of all parties that clicked on this web site; (2) immediately
remove all reference to, including all links to, this web site that is
located on your network; and (3) provide my office a writing agreeing
that said web site has been removed from your network and that your
company will cease and desist from allowing any further infringement of
our mark from occurring on your networks.

I have a good faith belief that the disputed use described above on the
allegedly infringing web pages is not authorized by the trademark owner,
its agent, or the law. I swear, under penalty of perjury, that the
information in the notification is accurate and that I am the trademark
owner or am authorized to act on behalf of the owner of an exclusive
right that is allegedly infringed.

If we do not receive a response within three days from the receipt of
this letter, we will assume that Everyones Internet is not interested in
resolving this matter on an amicable basis and will proceed accordingly.

If we are unable to resolve this matter amicably, we will file a lawsuit
at our discretion seeking: (i) preliminary and permanent injunctions,
(ii) compensatory damages, (iii) punitive damages, (iv) compensation
equal to your client's profits, (v) reimbursement of Jewelry Central's
attorneys' fees, and (vi) a court order that Everyones Internet
deactivate the infringing web site and that your client and Everyones
Internet compensate Jewelry Central for damage to it's goodwill.

Nothing in this letter shall be construed as limiting, in any way,
Jewelry Central's legal or equitable rights, including the right to
commence legal proceedings against your company and any other persons or
entities acting in concert with you, without further notice.

Very truly yours, 

William Decker,
Legal Department. 
http://www.jewelrycentral.com
